abstract.text: A structure that creates an unfair lock.

inlineContent.text: Unfair locks are low-level locks that block efficiently on contention. They’re useful for protecting code that loads stored resources. However, it’s unsafe to use
from Swift because it’s a value type and, therefore, doesn’t have a stable memory address. That means when you call
or
and pass a lock object using the
operator, the system may lock or unlock the wrong object.
Instead, use
, which avoids that pitfall because it doesn’t function as a value type, despite being a structure. All copied instances of an
control the same underlying lock allocation.
If you’ve existing Swift code that uses
, change it to use
to ensure correct locking behavior.

To create a lock that protects operation state, create an enumeration that contains the possible states, then create a lock object, passing the initial state. Here’s an example of what that looks like for an asset load operation:
Storing the state inside the lock helps track what the lock is protecting, and provides a way to safely access the state. To begin using the lock, call
or
, passing a closure that contains the code for the lock to protect, like in the following example:

To protect an operation with an externally defined state or no state, create a lock object without specifying an initial state. Nonscoped locking is more flexible, but offers no assistance in tracking the state of the operation the lock protects. To use a nonscoped lock, use
or
You can also use
with the more traditional lock/unlock approach by calling
before executing code that needs protection, and
upon completion, like this:
When using this approach, you must call
from the same thread you use to call
. Because of this, it’s unsafe to use this approach across an
suspension point. When using a lock with asynchronous code, lock using a closure or, even better, consider using an
isn’t a recursive lock. Attempting to lock an object more than once from the same thread without unlocking in between triggers a runtime exception.

abstract.text: Common protocol to which all actors conform.
Coordinate the scheduling and synchronization of your app’s tasks, and log information to the console to diagnose issues.
A structure that creates an unfair lock.
An enumeration that represents the ownership status of an unfair lock.
Creates a lock object that doesn’t protect state data.
Creates a lock object that maintains and protects state data.
Asserts if the lock object fails to meet specified ownership requirements.
A structure that contains the data for an unfair lock.
A low-level lock that allows waiters to block efficiently on contention.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
